title: 103_hr2535
content: AUTHORITY TO PROVIDE PRIORITY HEALTH CARE TO VETERANS OF THE PERSIAN GULF WAR. Inpatient care eligibility for veterans exposed to environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War is expanded under title 38, United States Code. Veterans may receive hospital and nursing home care for disabilities related to exposure, even without conclusive medical evidence. The eligibility for inpatient care for veterans exposed to environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War is expanded under title 38, United States Code. Veterans may receive hospital and nursing home care for disabilities related to exposure, even without conclusive medical evidence. Additionally, outpatient care provisions are also amended to include care before December 31, 1994. The eligibility for inpatient care for veterans exposed to environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War is expanded under title 38, United States Code. Veterans may receive hospital and nursing home care for disabilities related to exposure, even without conclusive medical evidence. Outpatient care provisions are also amended to include care before December 31, 1994. Additionally, medical services may not be furnished for disabilities found to have resulted from causes other than the specified exposure. The Secretary of Veterans Affairs will reimburse veterans for care related to exposure to toxic substances during the Persian Gulf War. Reimbursement will be based on payments made by veterans for hospital, nursing home, or outpatient services before the enactment of the Act. The Act extends certain health care and other authorities for veterans, including eligibility for care related to exposure to dioxin or ionizing radiation and sexual trauma counseling. The Act extends eligibility for sexual trauma counseling and other health care authorities for veterans, amending dates for various programs. SEC. 3. SHARING OF RESOURCES WITH STATE HOMES. The purpose of amending section 8151 of title 38, United States Code, is to improve care for veterans by allowing the Secretary to make agreements with State veterans facilities to share health-care resources. The definition of "health-care resource" is expanded to include various services and support. Sharing of health-care resources with State facilities is authorized under section 8153(a) of the title. The amendment allows the Secretary to make agreements with State veterans facilities to share health-care resources, including specialized medical resources and general health-care resources. The Secretary can enter agreements with State veterans facilities to share health-care resources, including specialized medical resources and general health-care resources, to avoid duplication and ensure efficient use of Department resources.
